Analysis of ATF data: The expert may have examined the data provided by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) to verify the claim. This could involve reviewing the statistics, reports, and records related to firearms recovered and traced in drug cartel crimes in Mexico.
Comparison with other sources: The expert may have cross-referenced the claim with information from other reliable sources to validate its accuracy. This could include consulting reports or studies conducted by independent organizations or government agencies that have investigated the origin of firearms in Mexican drug cartel crimes.
Review of methodology: The expert may have evaluated the methodology used to collect and analyze the ATF data. This could involve assessing the reliability and validity of the data collection techniques, the accuracy of the tracing process, and any potential biases or limitations in the methodology.
Expert knowledge and judgment: The expert may have utilized their own expertise and experience in the field of firearms trafficking and crime to assess the authenticity of the claim. This could include drawing upon their knowledge of patterns and trends in firearms trafficking, understanding of the dynamics between the United States and Mexican drug cartels, and familiarity with the challenges and complexities of tracing firearms.
